This is a follow-up on bug#4441.
The current config API and implementation of the 'config-warnings' key, to suppress well-known configuration warnings, is preliminary and marked 'experimental' in the manual. Finalize it. This probably means that the API and the implementation have to be re-thought.
- it is open which sub-keys are best for the config-warnings key (fixed keys like 'job-shadowing' which refer to a single warning; 'config-includes' which refers to an entire sub-action of the config system; variable keys like job keys that can be repeated literally in the config-warnings key; ...)
- it is unclear which values are best for those sub-keys: lists (as it is now), boolean, ... should mixed types be allowed?
- the current implement is ad-hoc; config-warning settings are queried just before the corresponding console.warn() call; as these console.warn() calls are distributed over the entire generator (at least generator.py, Generator.py and generator.config.*), so are the queries; more code like this will increasingly blur the actual effect code in the generator (the code that acutally *does* something); but there is no concept to e.g. delegate config-warnings settings to general log routines or something
- the top-level 'config-warnings' might itself become a sub-key of a more general 'defaults' top-level key
- i think the current way of integrating the top-level key with a single job (like with the global 'let') is ok
Of course answers also depend on usage experiences, feedback and future requirements.

One insight from working on bug#4615 is that it's probably best if warnings related to code are configured with some lint options for the lint/source/build/... jobs, or as @hints in the code itself. The config-warnings key could then be restricted to warnings that affect the config system alone (job definitions, job shadowing, include files, ...), which seems like a much better separation of concerns.

I think the best way is to separate purely config-related issues and issues having to do with JS code, as indicated in the previous comment. Code-related warnings should have their own dedicated tools to deal with. The remainder of the config-warnings key should be focussed on config issues only. This part (i.e. the affected config-warnings subkeys) could probably be left as is and this bug be closed, until concrete requirements show up to modify it in a certain way.
